com.github.fge.filesystem

Class MoreFiles

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.fge.filesystem.MoreFiles

  • @ParametersAreNonnullByDefault
public final class MoreFiles
extends Object
    Utility class to complement JDK's Files

    Unless otherwise noted, all methods in this class do not accept null arguments and will throw a NullPointerException if a null argument is passed to them.

    • Method Detail

      • copyRecursive

        public static void copyRecursive(Path source,
                 Path destination,
                 RecursionMode mode,
                 CopyOption... options)
                          throws IOException
        Recursively copy a source to a destination

        This command will work even across filesystems.

        Note that this command only supports directories and files. If the source is a symbolic link, though, it will be followed (see Path.toRealPath(LinkOption...)). Any symbolic link encountered during a copy will trigger an UnsupportedOperationException.

        There are two recursion modes: fail fast and keep going. In the first mode, copy will stop at the first error encountered and this error will be thrown. In the second mode, the copy will continue even if one or more errors are encountered and this method will throw a RecursiveCopyException. The list of exceptions which occured during the copy operations are available via Throwable.getSuppressed().

        The only supported copy option is StandardCopyOption.REPLACE_EXISTING.

        Parameters:
        source - the source to copy (either a file or a directory)
        destination - the destination
        mode - the recursion mode (see description)
        options - the set of copy options
        Throws:
        NoSuchFileException - source does not exist; or a parent of the destination does not exist when attempting to create the destination
        UnsupportedOperationException - unsupported copy option; or a symbolic link was encountered during copy
        FileAlreadyExistsException - StandardCopyOption.REPLACE_EXISTING was not specified, and the destination path already exists
        DirectoryNotEmptyException - StandardCopyOption.REPLACE_EXISTING was specified but the destination path is a non empty directory
        RecursiveCopyException - RecursionMode.KEEP_GOING was specified, however one or more errors were encountered during the copy operation
        IOException - other I/O errors (access denied, etc)
        See Also:
        MorePaths.resolve(Path, Path), Files.walkFileTree(Path, FileVisitor), Files.copy(Path, Path, CopyOption...), FailFastCopyVisitor, KeepGoingCopyVisitor

      • deleteRecursive

        public static void deleteRecursive(Path victim,
                   RecursionMode mode)
                            throws IOException
        Delete a path recursively

        Note that if a symbolic link is encountered, the symbolic link itself will be deleted. The target (if valid) is left untouched.

        There are two modes of operation: fail fast and keep going. In the first mode, deletion will stop at the first error encountered and throw the exception. In the second mode, deletion will continue, and this method will throw a RecursiveDeletionException. The list of exceptions encountered during the deletion operation is available using Throwable.getSuppressed().

        Parameters:
        victim - the victim
        mode - the recursion mode (see description)
        Throws:
        NoSuchFileException - victim does not exist (lucky you)
        RecursiveDeletionException - RecursionMode.KEEP_GOING was specified, and one or more errors were encountered during the deletion operation (see description)
        IOException - other I/O errors
        See Also:
        FailFastDeletionVisitor, KeepGoingDeletionVisitor, Files.delete(Path)

      • setMode

        @Nonnull
public static Path setMode(Path path,
                   int mode)
                    throws IOException
        Change POSIX file permissions of a path

        This method will take an integer as an argument, just like the Unix chmod command, with one difference: you must prefix the integer mode with 0 so that Java read it as an octal number; that is, use setMode(myPath, 0644) and not setMode(myPath, 644).

        Parameters:
        path - the path to change
        mode - the permissions to set, as an integer
        Returns:
        the path
        Throws:
        InvalidIntModeException - integer mode is not valid
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        IOException - failed to set permissions
        See Also:
        Files.setPosixFilePermissions(Path, Set), PosixModes.intModeToPosix(int)

      • setMode

        @Nonnull
public static Path setMode(Path path,
                   String permissions)
                    throws IOException
        Change POSIX file permissions of a path

        This command accepts a string representing the absolute POSIX permissions to set; for instance, setMode(thePath, "rw-r-----").

        Only classical modes are supported; you cannot set the suid bit nor sticky bit using this command. Attempting to do so will throw an IllegalArgumentException.

        Parameters:
        path - the path to alter
        permissions - the permissions to set, as a mode string
        Returns:
        the path
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - invalid permission string
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        IOException - failed to set the modes
        See Also:
        PosixFilePermissions.fromString(String), Files.setPosixFilePermissions(Path, Set)

      • createFile

        @Nonnull
public static Path createFile(Path path,
                      String permissions)
                       throws IOException
        Create a new file with a set of absolute POSIX permissions

        Files.createFile(Path, FileAttribute[]) can be used to set initial POSIX file permissions; however, those permissions are altered by the process' umask.

        This method is not "umask sensitive"; however, this means that unlike the command from Files, it is not atomic either: the file is first created, then the permissions are set.

        Parameters:
        path - the file to create
        permissions - the permissions to create the file with, as a mode string
        Returns:
        the created path
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - invalid mode string specified
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        FileAlreadyExistsException - the path already exists
        IOException - failed to create the file
        See Also:
        PosixFilePermissions.fromString(String), PosixFilePermissions.asFileAttribute(Set)

      • createFile

        @Nonnull
public static Path createFile(Path path,
                      int mode)
                       throws IOException
        Create a new file with a set of absolute POSIX permissions

        Files.createFile(Path, FileAttribute[]) can be used to set initial POSIX file permissions; however, those permissions are altered by the process' umask.

        This method is not "umask sensitive"; however, this means that unlike the command from Files, it is not atomic either: the file is first created, then the permissions are set.

        Parameters:

        mode - the permissions to create the file with, as an integer
        Returns:
        the path
        Throws:
        InvalidIntModeException - invalid integer mode specified
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        FileAlreadyExistsException - the path already exists
        IOException - failed to create the file
        See Also:

        Create a new directory with a set of absolute POSIX permissions

        Files.createDirectory(Path, FileAttribute[])} can be used to set initial POSIX file permissions; however, those permissions are altered by the process' umask.

        This method is not "umask sensitive"; however, this means that unlike the command from Files, it is not atomic either: the directory is first created, then the permissions are set.

        Parameters:

        permissions - the permissions to create the directory with, as a mode string
        Returns:
        the created path
        Throws:

        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        FileAlreadyExistsException - the path already exists
        IOException - failed to create the directory
        See Also:

      • createDirectories

        @Nonnull
public static Path createDirectories(Path dir,
                             String permissions)
                              throws IOException
        Create a new directory and all its missing parents with a set of absolute POSIX permissions

        Files.createDirectories(Path, FileAttribute[])} can be used to set initial POSIX file permissions; however, those permissions are altered by the process' umask.

        This method is not "umask sensitive"; however, this means that unlike the command from Files, it is not atomic either: the directories are first created, then the permissions are set.

        The permissions of already existing directories are not altered.

        Parameters:
        dir - the directory (and its missing parents) to create
        permissions - the permissions to create the missing directories4 with, as a mode string
        Returns:
        the created path
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - invalid mode string specified
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        IOException - failed to create the directory
        See Also:
        PosixFilePermissions.fromString(String), PosixFilePermissions.asFileAttribute(Set)

      • createDirectories

        @Nonnull
public static Path createDirectories(Path dir,
                             int mode)
                              throws IOException
        Create a new directory and all its missing parents with a set of absolute POSIX permissions

        Files.createDirectories(Path, FileAttribute[])} can be used to set initial POSIX file permissions; however, those permissions are altered by the process' umask.

        This method is not "umask sensitive"; however, this means that unlike the command from Files, it is not atomic either: the directories are first created, then the permissions are set.

        The permissions of already existing directories are not altered.

        Parameters:
        dir - the directory (and its missing parents) to create
        mode - the permissions to create the missing directories with, as an integer
        Returns:
        the created path
        Throws:
        InvalidIntModeException - invalid integer mode specified
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with this path does not support POSIX file permissions
        IOException - failed to create the directory
        See Also:
        PosixModes.intModeToPosix(int), PosixFilePermissions.asFileAttribute(Set)

      • touch

        @Nonnull
public static Path touch(Path path)
                  throws IOException
        Update the last access and modification time of a file, or create a file

        This command works similarly to the Unix touch command. If the given path does not exist, it is created (as an empty regular file); otherwise, its last access and modification time are changed to the current time.

        Parameters:
        path - the path to alter/create
        Returns:
        the altered/created path
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - the filesystem associated with the path, or the associated filesystem object associated with the path, does not support setting file times
        IOException - cannot update the times and/or create the file; other reasons
        See Also:
        System.currentTimeMillis(), FileTime.fromMillis(long), Files.createFile(Path, FileAttribute[]), BasicFileAttributeView.setTimes(FileTime, FileTime, FileTime)

      • changeMode

        @Nonnull
public static Path changeMode(Path target,
                      String instructions)
                       throws IOException
        Change POSIX file permissions of a file/directory using a chmod-like modification string

        The modification string is the same as chmod. For instance: 

             MoreFiles.changeMode(path, "o-rwx,g+r,g-w");

        See ModeParser.buildPermissionsSet(String) for the list of supported constructs.

        Parameters:
        target - the target to alter
        instructions - the modification instructions
        Returns:
        the target path
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - the target's filesystem does not support getting/setting POSIX file permissions
        IOException - failed to change permissions
